content.label: Essential Question
content.question:
Why does your iPhone cost $1,000 instead of $3,500 ‚Äî the estimated price if built entirely in the US?

International trade and comparative advantage create enormous value for consumers ‚Äî and directly shape jobs, prices, and opportunities in {{STATE_NAME}}.

terms.definition: The ability of a country to produce a good at a lower opportunity cost than another country ‚Äî the foundation of why trade benefits all participants even when one country is better at producing everything
terms.example: Even if the US is better than Mexico at producing both cars and tomatoes, it's most efficient for the US to specialize in cars and import tomatoes ‚Äî because cars represent a higher-value use of US labor and capital

terms.definition: A tax imposed by a government on imported goods, raising their price to protect domestic producers ‚Äî but also raising costs for consumers who buy those goods
terms.example: A 25% tariff on imported steel means a $1,000 foreign steel purchase costs $1,250 ‚Äî protecting US steel producers but raising costs for car and appliance manufacturers

terms.definition: The price of one country's currency expressed in terms of another ‚Äî fluctuates daily based on interest rates, inflation, economic growth, and market sentiment
terms.example: If $1 USD = 0.92 Euros, traveling to Europe costs you 8% more than if the rate were 1:1 ‚Äî strong dollar makes imports cheap and foreign travel affordable

terms.definition: When a country imports more goods and services than it exports ‚Äî the US runs a persistent trade deficit, meaning it buys more from the world than it sells to it
terms.example: The US 2023 trade deficit exceeded $900 billion ‚Äî Americans bought far more foreign goods (electronics, clothing, oil) than US exports sold to other countries

leftPanel.title: The Logic of Specialization
paragraphs: Countries (and people) benefit from specializing in what they produce most efficiently ‚Äî even if one country can produce everything better than another. Opportunity cost determines comparative advantage.
bulletPoints: Specialization ‚Äî Each country produces what it does best relative to alternatives, then trades for everything else
Lower Opportunity Cost ‚Äî Country A should produce good X if its opportunity cost (what it gives up) is lower than Country B's
Both Sides Gain ‚Äî Trade expands total output ‚Äî more goods are produced overall when each country specializes
Real-World Example ‚Äî {{STATE_NAME}} exports high-value goods (aerospace, agriculture, tech) and imports lower-value manufactured goods ‚Äî specialization at work

stats.label: Estimated savings per US household annually from lower prices due to trade
Annual US exports ‚Äî goods and services sold to other countries creating US jobs
Sides of a trade deal gain ‚Äî comparative advantage ensures mutual benefit

content.headerTitle: Tariffs and Quotas ‚Äî Trade Policy Tools

leftColumn.title: Tariffs (Import Taxes)
items: Raises the price of imported goods by the tax amount
Protects domestic producers from foreign competition
HURTS consumers ‚Äî they pay higher prices
Risk of retaliation ‚Äî trading partners impose their own tariffs on US exports like {{STATE_NAME}}'s agricultural products

rightColumn.title: Quotas (Import Limits)
items: Sets a maximum quantity of imports allowed
Protects domestic producers by limiting foreign supply
Often leads to trading partners seeking exemptions or retaliation through WTO dispute process

content.headerTitle: Exchange Rates ‚Äî How They Affect You

layoutData.title: The Dollar's Strength Touches Your Wallet
paragraphs: Exchange rates affect the price of everything you import ‚Äî from your iPhone to the gas in your car. They also affect your travel budget and the competitiveness of {{STATE_NAME}}'s exporters.
bulletPoints: Strong Dollar = Cheaper Imports: When $1 buys more foreign currency, imported goods cost less ‚Äî good for consumers in {{STATE_NAME}} buying electronics, clothing, and cars
Strong Dollar = Expensive Exports: US goods cost more in foreign currency ‚Äî hurts {{STATE_NAME}} farmers, tech companies, and manufacturers selling abroad
Weak Dollar = Cheaper Travel Abroad: Your dollar stretches further in countries with weaker currencies
Weak Dollar = More Expensive Imports: Foreign goods cost more in dollars ‚Äî bad for consumers but helps domestic producers compete

keyPoint.text: üí° Example: If $1 = 150 Yen and the dollar weakens to $1 = 120 Yen, a Japanese car priced at ¬•3,000,000 rises from $20,000 to $25,000 for US buyers ‚Äî a $5,000 price increase from currency movement alone.

leftPanel.title: How Trade Benefits Consumers and the Economy
paragraphs: Free trade ‚Äî the elimination of tariffs and trade barriers ‚Äî lowers prices, increases variety, drives innovation, and raises living standards. It's the dominant view among economists.
bulletPoints: Lower Prices ‚Äî Competition from imports forces prices down; consumers save thousands annually
Greater Variety ‚Äî Access to goods from around the world that couldn't be produced domestically at reasonable cost
Efficiency ‚Äî Resources flow to highest-value uses; specialization increases total economic output
Innovation ‚Äî Global competition pressures firms to innovate or lose market share
{{STATE_NAME}} Export Opportunity ‚Äî Access to 8 billion global customers for products {{STATE_NAME}} excels at producing

stats.label: Estimated annual savings for US household from cheaper goods due to global trade
US jobs supported by trade ‚Äî exports and imports create employment across the economy
Economists who support free trade as beneficial to overall economic welfare

leftPanel.title: Trade Creates Winners and Losers
paragraphs: While free trade benefits the economy overall, its costs are concentrated ‚Äî specific workers and communities can face devastating job losses while consumers broadly enjoy lower prices.
bulletPoints: Job Displacement ‚Äî Manufacturing workers in {{STATE_NAME}} face competition from lower-wage countries; 5M US manufacturing jobs lost since 1990s
Income Inequality ‚Äî College-educated workers gain from trade; less-educated workers often hurt by import competition
National Security Risk ‚Äî Depending on rivals for critical goods (semiconductors, pharmaceuticals) creates strategic vulnerability
Community Devastation ‚Äî Factory towns can collapse when plants close; impact concentrated geographically unlike diffuse consumer benefits

stats.label: US manufacturing jobs lost since 1990s ‚Äî attributed to trade and automation combined
Trade costs ‚Äî specific workers and towns devastated while benefits diffuse across all consumers
Trade Adjustment Assistance ‚Äî federal program helping displaced workers in {{STATE_NAME}} retrain

layoutData.title: Your State's Global Connections
paragraphs: {{STATE_NAME}}'s economy is deeply integrated with global markets. What {{STATE_NAME}} exports, what it imports, and which industries face international competition directly affects your job prospects and local economy.
bulletPoints: Export Opportunities: Industries where {{STATE_NAME}} excels globally ‚Äî aerospace, agriculture, technology, and advanced manufacturing ‚Äî create well-paying export jobs
Import Competition: Industries like textiles, basic manufacturing, and assembly work face intense competition from lower-cost countries, reducing those job opportunities in {{STATE_NAME}}
Supply Chains: Even 'American' products contain components from dozens of countries ‚Äî your car, phone, and appliances are products of global trade networks
Career Implications: Understanding {{STATE_NAME}}'s global competitive position helps you choose careers in growing export sectors vs. declining import-competing ones

keyPoint.text: üí° Every {{STATE_NAME}} resident benefits from trade through lower prices ‚Äî your annual savings from cheaper goods estimated at thousands of dollars. But workers in import-competing industries may face job displacement. Trade creates complex trade-offs between consumer and worker interests.

content.headerTitle: Free Trade Agreements ‚Äî USMCA and Beyond

leftPanel.title: How Trade Deals Affect {{STATE_NAME}}
paragraphs: Free trade agreements (FTAs) eliminate or reduce tariffs between countries, expanding market access for exporters and lowering costs for importers. The US participates in multiple FTAs affecting {{STATE_NAME}} businesses.
bulletPoints: USMCA (formerly NAFTA) ‚Äî Governs trade with Canada and Mexico; eliminates most tariffs; affects auto, agriculture, and manufacturing in {{STATE_NAME}}
Agricultural Access ‚Äî {{STATE_NAME}} farmers benefit from FTAs opening foreign markets to US crops and products
Dispute Resolution ‚Äî FTAs include mechanisms for resolving trade conflicts without escalating to tariff wars
Job Impact ‚Äî FTAs create export jobs in competitive industries while eliminating jobs in import-competing sectors ‚Äî net effect debated

stats.label: Annual US trade with Canada and Mexico ‚Äî USMCA's massive economic scope
Countries with US free trade agreements providing reduced tariff access for {{STATE_NAME}} exporters
World Trade Organization ‚Äî sets global trade rules and resolves disputes affecting {{STATE_NAME}} industries

scenario.name: Aisha ‚Äî Exchange Rates and European Travel
paragraphs: Aisha planned a 10-day trip to Europe from {{STATE_NAME}} and budgeted $3,000 for the trip based on an exchange rate of $1 = ‚Ç¨0.95. When she booked her hotel two months later, the dollar had strengthened to $1 = ‚Ç¨1.05.
Aisha's same ‚Ç¨2,850 budget now cost her only $2,714 ‚Äî she saved $286 simply because the dollar strengthened. Understanding exchange rates helps her time purchases and travel for maximum value.

scenario.name: The Johnson Farm ‚Äî Trade Policy and Agriculture
paragraphs: The Johnson family farms soybeans in {{STATE_NAME}} and relies heavily on exports to China ‚Äî their largest customer. When the US imposed $250 billion in tariffs on Chinese goods in 2018, China retaliated with 25% tariffs on US soybeans.

The Johnson farm's soybean revenue dropped 22% as Chinese buyers switched to Brazilian suppliers. Federal trade assistance payments partially offset losses ‚Äî illustrating how trade policy creates real winners and losers in agricultural communities.

content.question:
Think about a product you use daily that's made in another country ‚Äî your phone, clothing, or car. Should the US impose tariffs to protect domestic producers of that product?

Who would benefit from the tariff? Who would be harmed? How would it affect prices in {{STATE_NAME}}? Is the trade-off worth it? How do you weigh consumer savings against worker job protection?

As you plan your career in {{STATE_NAME}}, how does globalization affect your choices?

Are there industries in {{STATE_NAME}} that face significant international competition? Which sectors are growing because of export opportunities? How can you position yourself to benefit from global trade rather than be threatened by it?

takeaways.title: Comparative Advantage Drives Trade
takeaways.description: Countries specialize in what they produce most efficiently relative to alternatives ‚Äî both sides gain even when one country is better at producing everything

takeaways.title: Tariffs Protect Producers, Hurt Consumers
takeaways.description: Import taxes help domestic industries but raise prices for everyone ‚Äî the trade-off between worker protection and consumer savings is real and contested

takeaways.title: Exchange Rates Affect Everything
takeaways.description: Dollar strength determines import prices, travel costs, and competitiveness of {{STATE_NAME}} exports ‚Äî fluctuations create both opportunities and risks

takeaways.title: Trade Creates Winners and Losers
takeaways.description: Overall economic gains from trade are real ‚Äî but concentrated job losses in specific {{STATE_NAME}} industries require deliberate policies to assist displaced workers
